moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6
comment:
Ukrainian
chessplayers always like the Sicilian Dragon. I believe GM Mikhail Golubev,
one of the main experts of this sharp system, can confirm this.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4
comment:
the so called Rauzer Attack, though ,as far as I
know, the  Soviet theoretic Vsevolod Rauzer,  initially offered the set up
with

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5
comment: All this is the main theoretical line.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5
comment:
According to "official
theory" (omnibus databases like ChessBase or ChessAssistant) this move leads
to a difficult position for Black. So if Black decided to use it, he had to
have had some vital improvment in mind.   There are some alternatives here,
for example:

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5 18. Bxf6 Bxf6 19. exf5 Rxf5 20. Qxg4+ Rg5 21. hxg5
comment: This is a very nice tactical blow, but it's also well-known...

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5 18. Bxf6 Bxf6 19. exf5 Rxf5 20. Qxg4+ Rg5 21. hxg5 Bxg4 22. gxf6 Bxd1 23. Nc6
comment: The point - Black has to give back the queen.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5 18. Bxf6 Bxf6 19. exf5 Rxf5 20. Qxg4+ Rg5 21. hxg5 Bxg4 22. gxf6 Bxd1 23. Nc6 Bf3 24. Nxe7+ Qxe7 25. Rg1+ Kh8
comment:
This is a novelty. Maybe Areshchenko didn't know or forgot
the following game:

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5 18. Bxf6 Bxf6 19. exf5 Rxf5 20. Qxg4+ Rg5 21. hxg5 Bxg4 22. gxf6 Bxd1 23. Nc6 Bf3 24. Nxe7+ Qxe7 25. Rg1+ Kh8 26. fxe7 Re8 27. Nxb5 Ne5 28. Nxd6 Rxe7 29. Rf1
comment: White is a pawn up and has to win a second pawn. His position is winning.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 Nc6 8. Qd2 O-O 9. Bc4 Bd7 10. O-O-O Rc8 11. Bb3 Ne5 12. h4 h5 13. Bg5 Rc5 14. g4 hxg4 15. f4 Nc4 16. Qe2 b5 17. f5 gxf5 18. Bxf6 Bxf6 19. exf5 Rxf5 20. Qxg4+ Rg5 21. hxg5 Bxg4 22. gxf6 Bxd1 23. Nc6 Bf3 24. Nxe7+ Qxe7 25. Rg1+ Kh8 26. fxe7 Re8 27. Nxb5 Ne5 28. Nxd6 Rxe7 29. Rf1 Kg8 30. Nxf7 Rxf7 31. Kd2 Be4 32. Bxf7+ Nxf7 33. c4 Kf8 34. Kc3 Bb7 35. Re1
comment:
Now the king is unable to help his light pieces in their struggle against
White's passed pawn, so Black resigned.
